title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SALT LAKE CITY — The Delta Center bore witness to a performance for the ages Friday night, as Karl Malone powered the Utah Jazz to a 107-93 victory over the Orlando Magic. This was not merely a win; it was a masterclass, a historic dismantling authored by "The Mailman," who delivered a colossal 47-point, 13-reouble double.

From the opening tip, Malone was an unstoppable force, a study in power and precision. He carved through the Orlando defense with a ruthless efficiency, hitting turnarounds, bullying his way to the basket, and converting at the free-throw line. The Magic had no answer. Malone’s 47 points were not just a number; they were the relentless, pounding heartbeat of the entire contest, ensuring the Jazz never relinquished control.

While Malone dominated the scoring column, his partner in crime, John Stockton, orchestrated the destruction with a quiet 17-point, 13-assist double-double of his own. Each Stockton pass seemed to find Malone in perfect rhythm, their legendary synergy on full, devastating display. Jeff Hornacek provided crucial support with 20 points, stretching the floor and punishing any defense that dared to overcommit to the Malone onslaught.

Orlando, led by Rony Seikaly’s 19 points and 11 rebounds, simply could not keep pace with the historic eruption. The Jazz, fueled by Malone’s once-in-a-season performance, methodically built their lead and never looked back.

On this night, the story was singular and undeniable. The game was not about systems or strategies; it was about Karl Malone. In a display of pure, unadulterated greatness, he stamped his authority on the game and delivered a performance that would echo through the halls of the Delta Center long after the final buzzer sounded.
